newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian Telekom says 96 net profit down 7.4 pct.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian Telekom says 96 net profit down 7.4 pct.

text.p: Slovenian Telekom said on Tuesday its 1996 unrevised net profit fell to 2.5 billion tolars ($15.8 million) from 2.7 billion a year ago.
The company said state controlled prices which did not follow rises of costs in the company were among the main reasons for the drop in profit.
"We plan to increase our 1997 net profit to about three billion tolars following cost rationalisation measures introduced in the company," the company's spokesman Boris Ziherl, told Reuters.
He said Telekom's turnover in 1996 rose to 44 billion tolars from 36 billion in the previous year and announced an increase in this year's turnover to 48 billion tolars.
In 1997 Telekom planned to install 55,000 new telephone lines, about 10 percent more than in the previous year.
Ziherl said the plan is expected to be exceeded as in the first six months over 30,000 new telephone users were connected to the net.

Ziherl said the current number of 35 telephones per 100 inhabitants is expected to increase to 44, which is the average in the EU at the moment, by the year 2000 if development continues at its current pace.

He said Telekom's investment in enlargement of the country's telecommunications network this year is expected to amount to about 20 billion tolars, unchanged from the previous year. -- Novica Mihajlovic, Ljubljana newsroom, 386-61-125-8439
